metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof To the Point: Advising Students Applying to Obstetrics and Gynecology Residency in 2020 and Beyond

location.addrLine: Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center 50 330 Brookline Ave, Kirstein 3 51

abstract.text: Word Count: 219 55 Manuscript Word Count: 3240 56 57 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 4 58 Condensation: Faculty career advisors provide specialty-specific guidance for applicants to 59 Obstetrics and Gynecology residency, a vital resource during and after the COVID 19 pandemic. 60 61 Short Version of Title: "Advising students applying to OBGYN residency 2020" 62 63 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Abstract 64
This article, from the "To the Point" series by the Association of Professors of Gynecology and 65

Obstetrics Undergraduate Medical Education Committee, is a guide for advising medical 66 students applying to Obstetrics and Gynecology residency programs. The residency application 67 process is changing rapidly in response to an increasingly complex and competitive atmosphere, 68 with wider recognition of the stress, expense, and difficulty of matching into graduate training 69 programs. The COVID-19 pandemic and societal upheaval make this application cycle more 70 challenging than ever before. Medical students need reliable, accurate, honest advising from 71 faculty in their field of choice in order to apply successfully to residency. The authors outline a 72 model for faculty career advisors, distinct from mentors or general academic advisors. The 73 faculty career advisor has detailed knowledge about the field, an in-depth understanding of the 74 application process and what constitutes a strong application. The faculty career advisor 75 provides accurate information regarding residency programs within the specialty, helping 76 students to strategically apply to programs where the student is likely to match, decreasing 77 anxiety, expense and over-application. Faculty career advisor teams advise students throughout 78 the application process with periodic review of student portfolios and are available for support 79 and advice throughout the process. The authors provide a guide for the faculty career advisor in 80

Obstetrics and Gynecology, including faculty development and quality improvement. 81 82 Key Words: advising; faculty career advisors; medical students; Obstetrics and Gynecology 83 residency; undergraduate medical education. 84 85 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Matching Program (NRMP). 100 101 FCA Role and Responsibilities 102 The FCA fills a unique advising role, distinct from academic advisors, mentors, or 103 coaches. FCAs are knowledgeable about the specialty, application process, and residency 104 programs. 7,8 Despite up to 90% of faculty performing some career advising, the role is often 105 considered low-status. 9,10 While the FCA role is often considered part of CD duties, FCA's should 106 receive institutional recognition as advisors for the residency application process, and should 107 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f providing specialty-specific information about competitiveness and factors considered in 126 granting interviews and ranking candidates. 4,13 127 128 Early Career Advising 129 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Assembling the Application 188 Holistic Review 189 The FCA and student should review the Electronic Residency Application Service (ERAS) 190 application, including United States Medical License Examination (USMLE) and/or 191 Comprehensive Osteopathic Medical Licensing Examination (COMLEX) scores, grades, research, 192 teaching, volunteer and work experience, publications, and extracurricular activities. 193 Preferences for program size, type, location, and whether the student is couples matching 194 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Effective FCAs possess a deep understanding of the application process, residency 388 programs, and use holistic review techniques of student compatibility to maximize students' 389 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Application Response to COVID-19. [Internet] Accessed June 13, 2020. Available at 539 https://www.apgo.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Updated-APGO-CREOG-Residency-540 Response-to-COVID-19-.pdf. 2020. 541 42. Hampton BS, Cox S, Craig LB, Everett EN, Fleming A, Graziano SC, Hopkins L, McKenzie 542 ML, Morgan HK, Morosky C,Royce CS, Sims SM. Fourth Year Advising Project : Writing the 543 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f October 13-15, Chicago IL 563 564 48. Maruca-Sullivan PE, Lane CE, Moore EZ, Ross DA. Plagiarised letters of recommendation 565 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f OBGYN: Obstetrics and Gynecology; NRMP: National Residency Matching Program; 719 SOAP: Supplemental offer and acceptance program 720 721 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

body_text.text: Medical students often cite career advising as an area of unmet need, and rank guidance from Medicine (CiM) website. 14 Students can access CiM for career choice guidance. FCAs should 117 also be aware of student-led websites which may be less reliable than those of professional 118

Specialty FCA teams should meet regularly to review recent changes in the application 120 process, ensuring equitable, accurate advice for all students. Successful teams work together to 121 maximize outcomes for all students. 122

Medical students often have a limited understanding of the residency application 123 process. 4 Women, first generation and under-represented minority students may be less likely 124 to use networking or have mentors. 8 Once a student decides to pursue OBGYN, the FCA should assess a student's motivation 134 and ensure understanding of residency training commitments. 19 Discussing career goals, plans 135 for fellowship, research, advocacy, and topics such as abortion and assisted reproduction helps 136 the FCA guide students' program choices. 13 137

The FCA should review the student's curriculum vitae (CV) using the standardized AAMC 139 CV, or a school's recommended style. 14,20 The student should accurately describe activities and 140 research, taking credit for work done, but not overstating achievements. If a student 141 participated in research without a resulting publication, the FCA can recommend poster or 142 abstract presentation opportunities, or suggest writing a manuscript with the research mentor. 143
The CV should highlight activities highly valued by residency programs including 144 leadership, advocacy, teaching, honors and awards, such as the Gold Humanism Society and 145
Alpha Omega Alpha (AOA). Student membership in professional societies such as the American 146
College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) demonstrates commitment to the field. 147

The FCA should review potential weaknesses, including illness or adversities which 148 affected academic achievement. A low grade or score can be an opportunity to demonstrate 149 resilience. For students with a lapse in professionalism, legal action, or criminal conviction, the 150 successful match. 152
The FCA should also assess interpersonal skills and offer communications or public 153 speaking training if needed. 21,22 154
FCAs must understand the school's grading rubric and the Medical Student 155

Performance Evaluation (MSPE), the standardized narrative summarizing the student's 156 achievements, grades, evaluations, and class rank. 23 Many schools invite students to highlight 157 achievements for the MSPE. FCAs can advise students to list attributes based on personal 158 knowledge of the student and of factors valued by residency programs. 159
FCAs advise students on post-clerkship electives, research and extracurricular activities 162 to promote professional development and build a competitive portfolio. 18 163
Due to COVID-19, in 2020-2021 the AAMC recommended limiting away rotations to 165 students whose medical schools do not offer equivalent clinical experiences. 6,24 FCA's can 166

reassure students there appears to be no association between completing away electives and 167 matching at an institution, while a poor performance hurts a student's chances. 25 The FCA should ensure students meet with the Chair to discuss the departmental letter 180 of recommendation (LOR). 40 The Chair may delegate writing the LOR, but personal knowledge 181 of the applicant is desirable. The student should send the CV and personal statement for review 182 prior to the meeting, bring extra copies to the meeting, and be prepared to discuss their 183 application. Meeting with the department Chair helps build student confidence for interviews. The PS should focus on the student's goals, what the student seeks in and brings to 211 residency, rather than a patient or family story, or why the student chose medicine. 45, 46 The 212 tone should be professional and positive, avoiding criticism of the field, particular institutions, 213 or individuals. Weaknesses should be addressed in a psychologically safe manner, with an 214 emphasis on growth from adversity. 42,47 The FCA should proofread and suggest edits, but 215 refrain from revision. The PS should be the student's own work; a recent report found a 2.6% 216 incidence of plagiarism in the PS. 48 217
Modern professionalism includes cultivation of an online social media presence. 49 Over 219 half of PDs report screening applicants' social media for unprofessional behavior. 50-54 220

Reassuringly, a recent study of 87 OBGYN applicants found no unprofessional postings. 55 Social 221 media is also an opportunity for student networking with the medical community through 222 education, research, and commentary. 56-58 223 224

Interest in OBGYN has grown recently, with 5-6% of US medical school graduates and 2% 227 of foreign medical graduates entering OBGYN residencies. 30 applications. 61,65 Students frequently over-apply out of concerns for not matching. 7 FCAs can 270 guide students to limit the number of programs at which they apply through a strategic 271 approach including student interests, plans, and academic record. 272
body_text.section: Competitiveness of OBGYN as a Specialty 226

body_text.text: In deciding where to apply, students consider clinical interests, academic 273 competitiveness, geography, couples-matching, and finances. 13 Research and advocacy 274 opportunities, patient population and diversity are additional factors. FCAs can help students 275 limit the overall number of applications by considering other aspects of their planned career 276 paths in selecting programs at which to apply. For example, students interested in a non-277 academic career may consider community hospital programs over academic medical center 278 programs, while students planning to subspecialize may wish to apply to programs with 279 are certain they will not stay for residency. 281
body_text.section: Competitiveness of OBGYN as a Specialty 226

body_text.text: In determining the number of applications, the AAMC "point of diminishing returns" 282 tool (PDR) uses Step 1 scores to predict the number of programs needed to apply to match 283 successfully. 14 In OBGYN, applicants with a score >=230 needed to apply to 14 programs 284 (confidence interval, 13-15) to reach the highest likelihood of matching successfully: adding 285 more applications did not increase the chances of a successful match. For scores 214-229, the 286 PDR was 21 programs (CI, 19-23), with an 82% likelihood of matching. For scores < 213, the PDR 287 was 28 programs (CI, 26-30) with a 76% likelihood of matching. Approximately 90% of OBGYN 288 applicants ranking >=10 programs matched; over 99% of applicants ranking >=20 programs 289 matched. 14 Because of the decreased expenses associated with virtual interviews, students 290 may consider over-applying during the 2020 application cycle. FCA's can use the PDR to 291 encourage limiting the number of applications. In this fluid, competitive environment, less 292 academically competitive students may need to apply to up to 30 programs in order to receive 293 interviews (and thus rank sufficient programs), while highly competitive students may need 294 only apply to 10-14 programs . 5,7 295
body_text.section: Competitiveness of OBGYN as a Specialty 226

body_text.text: The process of deciding which programs at which to apply may become simplified with 296 proposed changes resulting from the pandemic, including more transparent communication 297 from programs regarding program values and desired applicant characteristics. 6 298
body_text.section: Competitiveness of OBGYN as a Specialty 226

body_text.text: The FCA can assist students with mock interviews and review recent graduates' 300 experiences. 21, 22 Since few students have experience with online interviews, FCA teams should 301 a pre-pandemic online interview pilot demonstrating equivalence of outcome with in-person 303 interviews may reassure students. 64 Students should explore program websites, and attend 304 online social events if offered, to understand programs' values, mission, and desired candidate 305 qualities. 6 During interview season FCAs should contact advisees regularly to review interview 306 invitations, reflect on impressions and rank programs as they complete interviews. 66 307
Students are often unsure about communicating with programs after interviews. 309

Programs generally welcome notification of new publications or awards. Students should not 310 falsely promise to rank a program first but may wish to inform a program of specific reasons 311 they are ranking a program first, such as a spouse at the same institution. Communication from 312 a program does not necessarily indicate a student will be ranked highly. Both candidates and 313 programs are governed in behavior and communication by the NRMP Code of Conduct which 314 prohibits programs from mandating second interviews, audition rotations, or asking how the 315 candidate will rank the program. 61 316

Prior to submission, the FCA should review students' rank list. Students should rank 318 programs in their preferred order. By ranking a program, the student is agreeing to 319 employment at that program. Students should not rank a program they do not wish to attend. 320
The NRMP recommends submitting the list before the deadline, as internet or website failures 321 have occurred. 61 322

FCAs should understand the special concerns of couples matching, described in detail at 325 the NRMP website (http://www.nrmp.org/couples-in-the-match/ ). For couples, each student 326 must rank the same number of programs or options, up to a total of 300 combinations of 327 residency programs , including "no match" options. 61 The couple will match to the most 328 preferred pair of programs on the rank order lists where each partner has been offered a 329 position (or a "no match" option is listed). A frank appraisal of each student's competitiveness 330 in their specialty is essential to ensuring the best match for both students. In general, both 331 students will need to apply to more programs than an individual student. 61 landscape evolves, the application process will undoubtably change, and specialty specific FCA 391 guidance will remain invaluable.

FIGREF0.text: 88 faculty career advisors (FCAs) in their chosen specialty as the most helpful resource in the 89 residency application process. 1-4 General advisors without an in-depth knowledge of the 90 specialty may provide inaccurate counseling, while clerkship directors (CDs) and residency 91 program directors (PDs) may not have time, resources or training to excel at career advising. 5 92 The rapid changes in the 2020-2021 application cycle due to COVID-19 demonstrate the need 93 for FCAs with both specialty-specific knowledge and an overall understanding of the application 94 process. 6 95 This article, one in the faculty development series To The Point, by the Undergraduate Medical 96 Education Committee of the Association of Professors of Gynecology and Obstetrics (APGO), is 97 intended as a guide to advising medical students applying for Obstetrics and Gynecology 98 (OBGYN) residency programs through the main residency Match of the National Residency 99 advisees . 9,11,12 There are no guidelines for the ideal student: advisor ratio, and in some 109 specialties FCAs advise over 20 students annually. 13 110 FCAs should frequently review the online resources published by the NRMP, Association 111 of American Medical Colleges (AAMC), and other national organizations (Table 1). These 112 websites are updated at least annually and provide a comprehensive view of the application 113 process, as well as updates on current conditions. The APGO OBGYN Residency Directory 114 provides a concise listing and comparison of residency programs, a vital resource for students 115 and advisors. Medical schools should provide FCAs with access to the AAMC Careers in 116

FIGREF1.text: 184 With current travel limitations, FCA teams can maximize networking through introductions to 185 faculty at desired programs with similar clinical or research interests. 186 should be discussed. The FCA can then suggest programs where the student is likely to receive 195 interviews. 196 Letters of Recommendation (LOR) 197 Students applying in OBGYN should submit at least 3 LORs including a letter from the 198 department Chair. 40 Due to the pandemic, the Council on Residency Education in OBGYN 199 (CREOG) and others recommend programs require fewer LORs for the 2020-2021 cycle. 6,41 200 FCAs should advise choosing faculty, research mentors, or project supervisors who know the 201 student personally and who can comment on strengths and fitness for residency. 40 Authors 202 from other specialties may be considered. Students should request a LOR at the time they work 203 with the author and meet to review their portfolio. Students should be mindful of the time 204 required to write LORs and request letters early enough to meet deadlines. 205 Personal Statement 206 The FCA plays a critical role in reviewing the personal statement (PS). 42 Although the PS 207is the only place in the application where the student's voice is heard, students often struggle 208 with writing. 42-44 A reflection exercise to identify strengths, weaknesses, career goals and 209 desired program characteristics leads to a well-organized, effective PS. 42 210

FIGREF2.text: Applicants increased from 1335 in 228 2010, to 2026 in 2019. 30 In 2020, there were 1413 PGY-1 spots, with 1.12 positions for each US 229 applicant. 30,59 230 Assessing Competitiveness 231 The FCA can help students assess their competitiveness in comparison with classmates 232 and with the entire applicant field. 26 To ensure adequate interviews for all students, FCA's 233 should advise students to apply strategically based on attributes valued at different programs, 234 as residency programs often interview only a few candidates per school. This requires FCA 235 teams to work collaboratively, equitably advising all applicants, are underway to simplify the application process. 60 In 2019, OBGYN 240 became the first specialty to recommend residency programs limit the number of invitations 241 extended to only the number of interviews available, standardize invitation dates, and give a 242 realistic response time to accept invitations. 60 243 244 Program Director's Perspective 245 Attributes Considered in Granting Interviews 246 PD's most frequently cite USMLE Step 1 scores as a factor in offering interviews, as 247 standardized tests are viewed as an objective measure of academic achievement and potential 248 for completing residency and passing licensing exams. 61 Most programs do not specify a 249 required Step 1 score, however in 2019 the median score for matched applicants was 229 250 (inter-quartile range, 218-240). 61 For less academically competitive candidates, including Step 2 251 scores in the initial application may boost chances for an interview. Other factors cited include 252 LORs, Step 2 scores, PS, and the MSPE. 30,59 Grades, class rank, publications, research, work or 253 volunteer experiences are less commonly cited factors. 254 In 2019 NBME announced Step 1 will become pass/fail; 62 the effects of this change are 255 uncertain, but may prompt the use of holistic reviews, and may change recommendations for 256 number of applications to submit. 6 257 Attributes Considered in Ranking 258 communication skills as the most important attribute. 61 While academic excellence is often 260 required to receive interviews, interpersonal skills are the deciding factor in ranking candidates. 261 In 2020, all interviews will be virtual. Although concerns exist this will adversely affect 262 perceptions of communication skills, 63 a pilot study in anesthesiology comparing virtual and 263 face-to-face interviews reported no difference in matching results. 64 264 265 The Application Process 266 Applying to Residency Programs: Which Ones and How Many? 267 Applying for residency is expensive and time-consuming. For OBGYN in 2019, students 268 submitted a mean of 61.3 applications, while programs received an average of 438.1 total 269

FIGREF3.text: Couples should 332 decide whether they are willing to train in different geographic locations or if either is willing to 333 delay training for a year. Couples should turn in their rank order lists early, as both applicants' 334 lists will be rejected if there are discrepancies, and must be resubmitted in time for the 335 deadline. 61 336 337 Supplemental Offer and Acceptance Process (SOAP) 338 Students are notified of match status on Monday of Match week. Applicants who have 339 not matched may then enter SOAP. Residency programs with open slots can contact students 340 directly during SOAP. Students, or their representatives, may not initiate contact prior to 3 pm 341EST on that Monday, and must go through ERAS to contact programs.67  Applicants in violation 342 of the NRMP rules can be barred from future participation in the Match.343 In the immediate post-match time frame, the FCA can offer support for the unmatched releases a list of unfilled programs. The FCA can assist the applicant in identifying programs as 347 FCAs may learn of open positions in the specialty before general advisors. 68 If an applicant does 348 not match through the traditional match but obtains a preliminary position, the FCA should 349 maintain contact, and offer to review a second application. 68,69 350 351 Effects of COVID-19 352 In response to the pandemic, most American medical schools suspended educational 353 and research activities in March 2020, resulting in decreased opportunities for students to 354 prepare for residency. Changes in the application cycle were instituted by the AAMC, while 355 APGO/CREOG recommended OBGYN specific changes. (Table 2). 6,70,71 356 As Ferrell and Ryan noted in April 2020, "The panic in the community is palpable, and 357 many are confused by how to proceed in the wake of COVID-19" as the normal methods for 358 demonstrating achievement are severely limited. 72 Students may face added stress from 359 societal upheaval, family illness, financial stress, and rising inequities. In light of the pandemic, 360 virtual mentor relationships such as FCA's remain the educational intervention most desired by 361 students. 73 APGO/CREOG specifically recommend students work with an FCA during this 362 application cycle. 41,74 FCAs should review recent general and OBGYN-specific changes to the 363 application process to accurately advise students. 6,60 . New FCA roles in 2020 include virtual 364 interview preparation and electronic networking. 63 365 FCA teams should update local student resources regularly. Medical schools should provide 369 current data, including programs where students have recently matched. FCA groups may 370conduct informal surveys or focus groups of graduates to elicit hard-to-capture data regarding 371 student experiences. 372Faculty Development 373The FCA is a novel role evolving to meet the needs of students during the residency 374 application process. The pool of faculty serving as FCAs may vary from school to school, 375 including subspecialists. While no formal training programs exist, APGO and other specialty 376 societies have published resources to assist faculty members as they develop the skills needed 377 to successfully serve as FCAs.18-22, 26,42  Online resources are listed inTable 1. FCA teams can 378 improve advising through standardized programs, sharing best practices, case-based critical 379 review of recent student experiences and reflection on their own experiences to inform 380 advising style and substance.75 381Continuous Quality Improvement 382 FCA teams should meet annually after the Match to debrief, inviting administrative staff 383 who often have a different perspective on student experiences. Recently, evaluation tools for 384 UME programs have been published and may be used to identify and adopt best practices.

TABREF0.text: ,16,17 FCAs can help achieve opportunity equity by meetings . 4 FCAs can help clarify career goals and identify research, extracurricular, and 131

TABREF1.text: FCAs should recommend electives to broaden medical knowledge, such as cardiology, 170 infectious disease, emergency medicine, dermatology, critical care, or neonatology. 13,25,33-35 171 Students should plan flexible schedules during interviews, complete an elective with direct 172 patient care in the months prior to graduation, and If available, a Transition-to-Residency 173 course. 34,36-38 A "Step Up to Residency" Program is offered at the annual ACOG meeting. 34,39 174 Some students take a fifth year; for less academically competitive students, research, 175 publications, or a second degree may bolster their portfolio. The FCA should maintain regular 176 contact with students during time away. At a minimum, hold a mid-year conversation to 177 confirm career plans and assure student well-being. 178

TABREF2.text: Online Advising Resources 685 The Road to Residency" Video series. Careers in Medicine AAMC Self-assessment for specialty choice. NRMP Detailed information for applicants and advisors on the couples matching process. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Wide Standards for the OBGYN Residency Application and Interview Processes. APGO Listing of all OBGYN residency programs in the United States and Canada with detailed program data and links to program websites. Residency Explorer AAMC Applicants can compare residency programs and applicant's profile to matched applicants at each program in 11 specialties. APGO Best practice guidelines for advisors in OBGYN.

TABREF3.text: COVID-19 Related Changes to the Residency Application Process 702• Learners who have a specialty interest and do not have access to a clinical experience with a residency program in that specialty in their school's system.• Learners for whom an away rotation is required for graduation or accreditation requirements.All programs commit to:• online interviews for all applicants including local students • virtual visits for all applicants including local students voluntary J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f • Release all interview offers on November 10 and November 17 • Limit the number of interview offers to the number of interview spots available • Allow a minimum of 48 hours for applicants to accept interview offers • Begin interviews no earlier than November 17 AAMC: Association of American Medical Colleges: APGO: Association of Professors of 704 Gynecology and Obstetrics; ERAS: Early Residency Application Service; MSPE: Medical student 705 performance evaluation; NRMP: National Residency Match Program 706 Figure 1: Timeline for Residency Application Process in Obstetrics and Gynecology 714
